Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Fairfield REU in Mathematics and Computational Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Fairfield University Research Experience for Undergraduates Program in Mathematics and Computational Science is an eight-week summer program designed to engage talented undergraduates in original mathematics and computing research beyond the standard college curriculum. The program hosts between nine and twelve students per summer, providing on-campus housing and student stipends. The students will typically come from institutions with limited access to faculty-sponsored summer scholarly activity for undergraduates, and students from groups that are underrepresented in mathematics and computing are especially encouraged to apply. Throughout the program, the participants work and learn in small groups, each group in close consultation with an individual Fairfield University faculty mentor on research topics drawn from the mentor's field of expertise.

The principal goal of the program is to prepare the participants for research-based scientific careers, and to engender in each student a deep understanding not only of the importance of individual scientific research, but also of the broader context of collaboration into which that research fits. This is achieved by providing the students with the experience of a research cohort, which is the motivation for the design of the program. By creating an environment of collaboration for the students and their faculty mentors, the program enables the means to achieve its goal, allows for the general advancement of the mathematics and computing disciplines, and fosters the continuing scholarly and pedagogical development of all the academic professionals involved in the program.

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Fairfield University Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Summer Program in Mathematics and Computational Science has actively engaged talented undergraduates in research mathematics and computational science since 2011. As of 2014, Fairfield University has hosted 35 students (each student for two summer months) for the purpose of conducting original research under the expert guidance of Fairfield University faculty mentors. The goal of the program is to help maintain and strengthen the scientific research base of the nation. The participating students have come from across the country and represent every type of full-time U.S. undergraduate educational institution. Women have made up nearly half of the participants, in accordance with the program goal of broadening national involvement in advanced scientific research. The research work has engaged a total of 10 regular Fairfield University faculty from the disciplines of Mathematics, Computational Science, and Engineering. 

 

The Fairfield REU effectively contributes to the mathematics and computing scientific research landscape. Each research group to date has presented new research results at national scientific meetings, and most of the research groups have published or plan to publish the results of their work in professional journals in their disciplines. Students in the Fairfield REU have produced results in cybersecurity, algorithms, the evolution of mathematically complex systems, statistical analysis of regional water quality, and new theoretical results in geometry and algebra. The evaluation component of the program, in which the student participants engage in workshops together on their learning experiences, has produced new ideas and questions for pedagogical research that Fairfield University faculty are actively pursuing in order to better understand the changing face of the American science and mathematics undergraduate researcher. The program participants who have since graduated have gone on both to industry careers in computing and analysis and to graduate education in the sciences, most citing their experience in the Fairfield REU as a significant factor in their decisions, and all, most importantly, having had the experience of the collaborative cohort environment in which scientific research actually occurs.
